history.subject: Updated Sample/Suggested Program Plans for EECS majors
history.content:
There is a bug preventing me from getting these on the website tonight, so posting them here with the expectation that folks will be planning their Spring classes this weekend. Please note that these plans are for EECS majors and reflect no new changes in requirements, just a change in course order, as recommended by some of our lower division faculty.

Students with Math 1A completed in high school.pdf

Students with Math 1B completed in high school.pdf

Students without Math 1A or 1B.pdf

children.subject: When you put it this way, EECS doesn't seem bad at all!
Are there similar plans available to CS/intended CS students? I remember seeing some my freshman year, but with the site change, I'm not sure where they are now.

The EECS plans can be tweaked to provide exactly what you want based on your Mathematics background coming into Berkeley. Just replace the non-EECS courses appropriately to reflect L&S college breadth requirements. But I will recommend the same lower-division EECS sequence for L&S CS students because that is really the best way to be adequately prepared. At this point, the within-major course requirements are essentially harmonized across the two majors offered by the EECS department.  

The EECS lower-division and its logic is really simple to understand. There are two 3-course sequences: 61A, 61B, 61C and 16A, 16B, 70. Each of these sequences ramps up difficulty and nurtures students so that they are ready for the next course.  At the last step, the two trilogies interweave somewhat with 61B being gently helpful for 70 as compared to 16B which is directly helpful in terms of core skills. Meanwhile, 16B is gently helpful for 61C while 61B is directly helpful. 

These sample plans are really most helpful in understanding the sequencing of lower-division courses. The deeper logic behind the upper-division is not represented here because at that point, there are many choices and tracks based on your interests across the modeling/math/algorithms, software development, and hardware development pathways. All that can be said confidently about the upper-division is that essentially everyone should take 170.

history.subject: CS 191: Quantum Mechanics and Quantum Computation
history.content:
C/PHY/CS 191: Quantum Mechanics and Quantum Computation

Instructor: Prof. Umesh Vazirani
TuTh 11-12:30 306 Soda Hall (HP Auditorium)

Spring 2017 

 

Quantum computation is a remarkable subject building on the great computational discovery that computers based on quantum mechanics are exponentially powerful. This course aims to make this cutting-edge material broadly accessible to undergraduate students, including computer science majors who do not have any prior exposure to quantum mechanics. The course starts with a simple introduction to the fundamental principles of quantum mechanics using the concepts of qubits (or quantum bits) and quantum gates. This treatment emphasizes the paradoxical nature of the subject, including entanglement, non-local correlations, the no-cloning theorem and quantum teleportation. The course covers the fundamentals of quantum algorithms, including the quantum fourier transform, period finding, Shor's quantum algorithm for factoring integers, as well as the prospects for quantum algorithms for NP-complete problems. We will also discuss the basic ideas behind the physical implementation of qubits and quantum gates, as well as progress in the experimental realization of quantum computers.

THE FACULTY OF THIS COURSE ARE NOT READING THIS THREAD. YOU SHOULD DIRECT YOUR QUESTIONS TO THEM VIA EMAIL.

children.subject: What are the hard/soft prerequisites for this class?

In the past, it was

Mathematics 54, Physics 7A-7B, and either Physics 7C, Mathematics 55, or Computer Science 170

No clue if that still remains true, but it seems likely from the description.
There are no --have never been -- official prerequisites to the course.   That doesn't mean individual instructors haven't shared a list like this in various offerings of the course. Interesting.
Will this be offered in either Fall 2017 or Spring 2018 semesters?
Probably not...perhaps the next year.
Are there other courses at Cal to learn quantum computing?
(for example, is CS294-2 quantum computation planning to be offered next year?)

Courses to be offered for next academic year have not yet been committed to.  As soon as we are able to,  the tentative (draft) schedule for F17/SP18 will be listed here :  https://www2.eecs.berkeley.edu/Scheduling/CS/schedule-draft.html?_ga=1.62538732.1945271187.1416977033 

This is likely to occur in or by early January.
What's the CN?
It hasnt been put onto schedule, so we dont have a cn yet (i think)
+1 Based God
Let's do it.
Is there a final exam? I really want to take this class, but I have a time conflict.

I have a time conflict as well. I am curious if this will be webcasted or not, and if alternate final times would be offered...

I'm graduating too so its my last chance to take it :(
The class is set up to have a final exam.  We don't normally webcast courses whose enrollment is as relatively small as this one. Sorry.
Can we sign up for it as soon as it is opened? Or do we have to wait for our phase 2?
You can't do anything until your phase II
Any idea when this class will be in schedule for those of us who already are able to do their phase II?

Either Monday or the following Monday.

Apologies for delay, cross-listing with three departments, new CalCentral...ugh!

Thank you! 
Apologies for the delay not needed, merely was hoping for specific days to check so I didn't have to check throughout thanksgiving. Thank you so much!
Do Chemistry majors in the College of Chemistry have reserved seats?
https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs/enrollment-policy
This is true to enroll via cs.  Of course, the chem and physics sections will have their own policies to follow.

What's the relevant material from Physics 7A and 7B? 
I am LSCS so I didn't take those particular courses, but I've taken other physics courses and I'm wondering what material I should look up if I'm interested in taking this class.
Physics 7C is really the course that covers quantum (and optics) and topics which are not absolute prerequisites for all engineers e.g. civil to materials science
How many units is this class?
3 units.

What is the workload of this class like? Is the homework mostly in the form of programming or solving problem sets? 

 I am taking physics 137A this semester and the homework is basically solving problems. I wonder if it is similar for this class? Thanks!!!
Fa 14 homeworks looks like problem sets. (I'd also be impressed if they thought up some programming assignment involving quantum systems)
Thanks!
How will the in-person version compare to the archived online version on edX?
The in-person version is better.
In what ways? There is obviously the opportunity to talk with instructors about the material, but are there content differences? Updates to the approach? More extensive material?
I'm curious as well. Seeing as there's no discussion section, just seeing an in-person lecture isn't a huge draw
I'm curious as well, especially given that the instructor (Vazirani) is the least approachable professor I have ever seen in the 4 yrs I've been here.

The class is up! It's listed under Physics on schedule.berkeley.edu.
CCN: 34072
Thanks for the heads-up!
Thanks!

CCNs for CS and Chem in case physics fills up.

COMPSCI: 34017

CHEM: 34073

PHYSICS: 34072
any hope of it being webcasted?
yes, I have hope
If it's being taught in HP then unlikely. That room wasn't equipped for webcasts last year so it's probably not possible even if professor vazirani wants to.
It says waitlist is full when I try to add the class. Did it really fill up that quickly?
[Wait, you said waitlist, not lecture. Waitlist looks like it should be open, according to schedule.berkeley.edu]
hmm that's weird. When I try to add the class it says that the waitlist is full.
What are the official pre-reqs?
You can look that up at http://guide.berkeley.edu
No prereqs listed there... although someone above in this thread quoted the 7 series and more.

That means there are no official prerequisites to the course.  It is likely that means that the various department faculty knew that students would come to the course with various levels of preparation received via various pathways.
Can i sign up for the physics or chem sections but still get credit for a cs upper div?
Yes. I learned today that the department will give one credit towards the major or minor (as an upper div cs course) for taking this course no matter which department is used to enroll.
Will there be alternate final exams offered? I have to take Math 110 next semester, which has the same lecture time as this class.
Unlikely, but you can ask Prof Vazirani.

Why does each department have its own enrollment list? Are all waitlists unified in ordering (e.g. someone in the CS category can be enrolled after someone from Chem drops) or does someone in the CS category have to drop before someone else is added to the CS category?
Because that's what the faculty who created this course wanted.

Cross-listed courses allow each department to set its own enrollment policy (e.g. prioritizing its own majors), allow students of both/all departments involved to be able to choose whether to treat the class as a class in their department for their major or outside as a breadth, et cetera.

In the old enrollment system, at least, enrollment for the different departments' versions of a cross-listed class was completely separate. Can't tell if this is still the same.

Thanks Steven.  In this case, the new system is actually more flexible.  What I mean, is that in a cross-listed course, the departments can set a global enrollment limit X and the sum of the enrollment limits for the multiple sections don't have to = X.  The sum can be > X so that while no more than X students can sign up for the class as a whole, it may be that for some or all of X there is no system preference for which department is used as the vehicle for an individual student to sign up.

C191 is set up that way with current enrollment max of 64 students being accessible from any of the three listings.
I still can't find the class CN or in the scheduler! Am I doing something wrong?
They were posted earlier in this thread.
If I'm a CS major, should I sign up for the wait list under the CS department? CS has a much longer wait list than Physics or Chem.
Similarly, as an Engineering Physics major, should i pick the physics dept? I would need this to count for an upper div cs requirement for an EECS minor, so I'm currently on the CS waitlist.
I learned today that the department will give one credit towards the major or minor (as an upper div cs course) for taking this course no matter which department is used to enroll.

Does it matter which of the three departments I sign up for? I want to use this class towards a physics minor, but I'm enrolled in the Chem department's C191. I figure it shouldn't matter since it's the same class.
No. I learned today that the department will give one credit towards the major or minor (as an upper div cs course) for taking this course no matter which department is used to enroll.
Do you know if this is true for all three departments?
I only know this is true for cs/eecs/

Is the class likely to get expanded? Based on the response to the Facebook post on the CS group, I think a lot of students are going to be disappointed if they are not able to take the course next semester.
same
No. It is not likely to get expanded.
Will the Chemistry / Physics versions of the class be graded on the same curve? I am not sure if I should stay on the Chem waitlist.
asking the right questions
I think so but that is completely up to the instructor so you should feel free to approach Prof Vazirani.
Why is the class closed? CalCentral says the wait list capacity is 120 and there are only 78 on the wait list
"Closed" means something in calcentral but not necessarily what we would expect it to.

Are seats being saved in each section for the respective majors? The Chemistry section only had 5 people enrolled when I was 1st on the waitlist, and now it has 6 people enrolled but I'm still 1st on the waitlist.

Secondarily, how many seats are being allocated for each section?

To have a discussion about the chemistry department's management of their enrollment lists, you'll have to reach out to staff in Chemistry.

In terms of are there seats set aside for specific department's entry: no. There are 64 seats total and any department can enroll anywhere from 0 t 64 students as long as the final total is =/< 64.
Is there a way to find out who's managing the chem waitlist?
I'd contact the advisors in Chemistry; they either are or know who are the relevant parties that manage the chem waitlist.

history.subject: Special Topics CS 294/194-133: Collaborative Intelligent Agents and The DARPA Spectrum Challenge
history.content:
Dear students,

I am going to be offering a special topics course this Spring. It will be held MW 1-2:30pm in 310 Soda. 

This should be a room-shared 194 and 294 pair. This is open to undergrads and grad students. 

At some point, it will show up on the campus systems.

194 Course Description:

This research/project-oriented course is about bringing artificial intelligence techniques based on machine learning and adaptation to the problem of collaboration rather than competition. Can we make agents that can learn to collaborate with each other without such agents having to be codesigned from the start? This is an emerging research frontier. To make things concrete, we will use the new DARPA Spectrum Collaboration Challenge as a key example. In the last decade, DARPA challenges were instrumental in kicking self-driving car technology into high gear. This new challenge aims to do the same for collaborative intelligence. Berkeley is going to be fielding a team in this challenge next year.
The hope is that many of the course projects will evolve into research papers, and if desired, continue into undergrad summer research positions that could go on through next year. 
 
Students do not require a wireless background to participate, as we will do a quick pass through the basics of wireless communication and networking as a part of this course. Students will have to present papers as a group, but the majority of the grade will be based on group projects (students will have wide leeway to come up with these, and I will also have some suggestions) and the course is open to a diverse set of backgrounds. If the course is oversubscribed, we will be selecting students to get a good mix of backgrounds. In particular, students with a background in human computer interaction are particularly welcomed, as are students with backgrounds in networking and those with a background in learning. 
UPDATE: 
Here is the application form: https://goo.gl/forms/NmPwpiBWKxt0yZZo1

history.subject: Special Topics CS 294/194-133: "Collaborative Intelligent Agents and The DARPA Spectrum Challenge"
history.content:
Dear students,

I am going to be offering a special topics course this Spring. It will be held MW 1-2:30pm in 310 Soda. 

This should be a room-shared 194 and 294 pair. This is open to undergrads and grad students.

194 Course Description:

This research/project-oriented course is about bringing artificial intelligence techniques based on machine learning and adaptation to the problem of collaboration rather than competition. Can we make agents that can learn to collaborate with each other without such agents having to be codesigned from the start? This is an emerging research frontier. To make things concrete, we will use the new DARPA Spectrum Collaboration Challenge as a key example. In the last decade, DARPA challenges were instrumental in kicking self-driving car technology into high gear. This new challenge aims to do the same for collaborative intelligence. Berkeley is going to be fielding a team in this challenge next year.
The hope is that many of the course projects will evolve into research papers, and if desired, continue into undergrad summer research positions that could go on through next year. 
 
Students do not require a wireless background to participate, as we will do a quick pass through the basics of wireless communication and networking as a part of this course. Students will have to present papers as a group, but the majority of the grade will be based on group projects (students will have wide leeway to come up with these, and I will also have some suggestions) and the course is open to a diverse set of backgrounds. If the course is oversubscribed, we will be selecting students to get a good mix of backgrounds. In particular, students with a background in human computer interaction are particularly welcomed, as are students with backgrounds in networking and those with a background in learning.

children.subject:
How much work would this be, say, compared to your offering of 16B last semester?

This class sounds very interesting, but I don't want my life to RIP, so I need to schedule accordingly.

This is going to be qualitatively very different from a very structured course like 16B with weekly homeworks, discussions, etc. Students will be expected to have a lot of self motivation, to engage with the material, and to really put a lot of effort into their projects. So, I think that about 12ish hours per week on average is what you should expect to be putting in. It really depends a lot on the projects, but this isn't a do-it-all-in-three-nights kind of project.

For example, one kind of project that I want for sure to have at least one team on (with HCI background) is to develop a human-playable networked game so that we can see how humans can learn how to collaborate/coordinate with strangers playing alongside them. If a team was to make a simple framework to make such games, make a game within that framework that exhibited the kinds of phenomena that we'll see in the DARPA challenge, had people play that game using say Mechanical Turk or some other platform by which we could have multiple people play the game to collect some data, and then analyzed that data to say something about collaborative intelligence --- this would be a solid A project. If the framework was made in a way that also let us drop in some AIs to see how they play against people, this would be a solid A+.  This work could then turn into a paper and further research down the line if the students want to. 

Another kind of project that is still fine for the course would be a replication plus plus type study --- where a group replicates a result like the recent Google paper on learning encryption and then augmented it to see if a similar neural network can learn to modulate and error-correct alongside. So lots of flexibility here. 

Over the course of a semester, this kind of thing I think is very reasonable to do with a team of 3 students working together. We might allow some mixed grad-student/undergrad teams as well. This way, a willingness to work hard in implementation, learn things well on your own in a group (talking to me and your fellow students along the way) and learn even more while you do so is enough to allow an undergrad to participate.
How many units will this be?
3 units, but those are EECS units :-)

I'm very intrigued by this course and am really interested in taking it. However, my background is primarily in Math and Statistics, and my experience in CS is largely restricted to AI/ML/basic theory. Do you think this course might prove too inaccessible for someone with such a background? I have extensive experience with self-learning and a pretty strong work ethic, so I'd be willing to fill any small gaps in my knowledge on my own; just would like an idea as to how small/large those gaps might be.

This should be fine, especially if you are willing to work in a team with others whose skills complement your own. 

If the course is oversubscribed, I will select students so that I have the best mix of diverse backgrounds to help the course as a whole succeed. I wouldn't want a classroom filled with only one kind of student. The problems here are new and challenging, and I want this course to actually help move the ball forward in terms of understanding and research. This takes different points of view.
Perfect. Is there a application already available to apply to enroll in the course?
Just register and we will sort out applications closer to the start of Spring term.
Any idea what date the apps come out?
Can't seem to find it on CalCentral (classic). Is there a course number to enroll?
Found it.
For anyone else who has trouble finding it, if you add the CS 194 class, it allows you to pick which section that you want if you click the Options button.
What kind of pre-reqs or experience do we need?

Realistically, the lower-division 16A,16B,70 plus 170 is probably sufficient to bring your math up to the level needed to follow. I'd like students to have one of: 160, 168/122, or 189. This way, I am more confident that you can find a project path that works for you. If you took 290S with Prof. Ramchandran, then that is certainly more than sufficient, and certainly not required. 

I want to have a diverse group of backgrounds for maximum creativity.

Does the application process mean that even though you may be enrolled right now, you may get dropped later if too many students with your background/experience sign up? I have limited Phase 2 units so just wondering how likely it is that I will stay in the course.

Yes. If there is more demand than seats in the course, then I will select on the basis of applications, not first-come first-serve. The goal is to maximize the overall creativity of the course as a whole. 

It is hard to say how likely anything is because this course has never been offered before and it is designed to be on the cutting edge.

Hi Professor Sahai - 

Would you recommend using Phase 2 units or to wait until adjustment period to add the class?
There is no point in using scarce units since the application process won't take when you added into account as more than a tie breaker.
When would you be reviewing the applications? I just saw this announcement, and am now hoping to add this course during the adjustment period. Would that be too late?

Hey Professor Sahai - 

Should I add myself to the waitlist for the class during adjustment period because calcentral currently lists the class as having no available seats?
Seems interesting. Is there a plan to present this class in any future semesters?

As of now, consider this a one-off course.

Certainly the content will evolve if I ever offer this again, hopefully because the next course will get to study the results obtained by the group of students in this offering. The goal here is to substantively move the needle on the understanding of this area over the span of the semester.

"Can we make agents that can learn to collaborate with each other without such agents having to be codesigned from the start? This is an emerging research frontier." 

Seems like an interesting question - are there any papers that you can point us to that address that question specifically or perhaps indirectly? I'm sure, many of us would love to read something to get more context.

The most on-point paper conceptually is one from Madhu Sudan (Berkeley alum, former MIT, former MSR, now at Harvard) but it uses a computational complexity framework that is not quite a perfect fit for the deeper issues here.

There are also papers in evolutionary biology on the evolution of cooperation.
Is there some sort of waitlist we can signup for to be notified when the application process opens?
Any updates on the application?

Here is the application form: https://goo.gl/forms/NmPwpiBWKxt0yZZo1

In case you missed the first lecture of the course. All undergrads must fill out the application so that the course has the right mix of diverse perspectives and backgrounds.

history.subject: [ADVICE] Getting A's on exams
history.content:
CS major here. I need some advice: How to perform above average on exams. In all my technical classes here, I'm always

+- .5 STDs from the mean. Consequently, I'm a solid B student.

 No matter how hard I study, I always perform around the same. The problem is that I'm not studying the right way. There's always problems on the final I just don't know how to do. I'm not mastering the material like I should.

How should I be studying?

This is what I do currently.
1. Write down everything I need to know.
2. Re-do all discussion WSs, cross off items.
3. Practice weak areas from old exams.
4. Do (untimed) practice exams.

I'm taking 61C and 170 next semester. I'd especially appreciate if Yujie, Steven Bi and other TAs replied.

history.subject: [ADVICE] Getting A's on exams
history.content:
Hi everyone,

CS major, second semester at Cal. I need some advice: How to perform above average on exams. In all my technical classes here, I'm always

+- .5 STDs from the mean. Consequently, I'm a solid B student.

The problem isn't that I don't study enough. No matter how hard I study, I always do around the same. The problem is that I'm not studying the right way. There's always problems on the final I just don't know how to do. I'm not mastering the material like I should.

How should I be studying?

This is what I do currently.
1. Write down everything I need to know.
2. Re-do all discussion WSs, cross off items.
3. Practice weak areas from old exams.
4. Do (untimed) practice exams.

I'm taking 61C and 170 next semester. I'd especially appreciate if Yujie, Steven Bi and other TAs replied.

I'm able to get A's by doing the following:

Going to all the discussions.

Going to all the lectures (Or watch the videos but don't fall behind!)

Try to stay at least 3 lectures ahead of the class.

Read the book / notes or whatever and don't just rely on the slides.

Try to do the homework without someone else's help.

Do / go over 5 or more exams.

Edit:

I am a junior year student and got A or A+ in all CS courses. (usually in top 3%) Here are what I do:

1. Going to all the lectures. It is really important!

2. Do homework alone! I never do homework in a group since I know I can't sit in a group when doing exams. Thus I always do homework by myself and sometimes discuss with my friends online if there are some confusion.

3. Do a lot of past exams. (usually around 6) This is really important also. Some questions have pattern and you will be in advantage if you have solved similar problems before.

4. I seldom attend discussion actually since I personally don't think it's the most efficient way. I am more used to doing discussion worksheet by myself when solutions are posted online.

5. I never try staying at least 3 lectures ahead of the class. But maybe it is a good way.

You left out reviewing the homework in the list of things you currently do. Especially for a class like CS170, when some problems of the homework can be harder than many of the problems on the exam, and when exam problems have been written explicitly with the homework in mind, this is a large oversight.

children.subject:
Terrific answer Anon.

Can you explain these two more?

a. Try to stay at least 3 lectures ahead of the class.

b. Read the book / notes or whatever and don't just rely on the slides.

Thanks again.

Not OP but for b, if material is harder to consume and understand, it will "stick" more and you'll end up understanding it better. When someone is making concepts clear and easy to understand, its easy to fool yourself into thinking you've learned them.

a. Try to learn the week's material over the weekend, before the week starts.

b. If there is a textbook or recommended supplement, read it because it will be helpful. Just going over the lecture slides is not enough...

Hope these help :)

What do you do to avoid falling behind? Personally, whenever I have a major project or exam, I drop everything and work on it (to avoid screwing up). Then I'm behind for the next week and have to self-study. And this cycle continues.

By going to lectures / discussions? They take only a few hours...

And asking yourself the question: "How much of your 'studying' time are you actually studying?"

I'm sometimes shocked by the answer myself lol...
Also, sometimes it helps to learn or know some of the material beforehand. You still have a month.
Sahai created this schedule. Does it apply for non-CS 70 classes?
Sure, that's more or less the same idea as the answer above.
I think this probably is a little much... I don't know anyone who actually spends this much time on a single class consistently

I think that the listing of the sorts of activities that are useful to do on a regular basis (e.g. actually reviewing the solutions to previous homeworks instead of just being satisfied with getting full points on a problem, first trying the homework on your own for a few hours and then work on the problems with your study group) is more useful than the actual time allotted for each of the activities.

That is, scale the numbers down if you want, but the list of activities is pretty reasonable.

When should you study alone and when should you study in a group?

In a group, your questions get answered more quickly but you can also just pretend like you know what's going on. Alone, everything takes longer but you're forced to learn it yourself. That's my take on it.

Also when studying alone, your mileage may vary. When studying in a group, some people will ask questions that will really test the extent of your knowledge. If you don't think you can get that kind of coverage on your own, study in a group.

I noted above the suggestion of first trying studying alone, and then meeting with your group, when you've already tried some ideas (whether or not they work). See if your groupmates had the same ideas, and brainstorm more together if none of them work.

But if you're pretending that you understand something when in your group, then that's probably not going to be very effective / a separate problem to handle (e.g. if it's a confidence/embarrassment issue).

What sleeping schedule do you suggest? When do you suggest sleeping and waking up? 

I know it's a "depends on you" question, but I want to know what A students do.

I think when you sleep and get up is completely irrelevant to your grade as long as you get enough sleep... I know someone who got an A in CS 70 who slept at 6 am every day during dead week (and got up at like 2 pm).
is he a CS God?
Not particularly, he got a B in CS 61A.
How important is office hours? Do you go regularly or only if you have a specific question/
I just ask on piazza

Office hours for CS classes in my experience tend to be rushed and unhelpful because the TA's have limited time and lots of people to deal with. On Piazza you'll usually get a thoughtful answer promptly.
Try going to office hours when there is no homework/projects due. It's pretty fun to pick at the TAs brains.

Upper div office hours are certainly smaller than those for lower divs (or more specifically: office hours for smaller courses have fewer people), and the timing of the week matters quite a bit as well. Certainly, the earlier the office hours (with respect to when the assignment is due), the less crowded it'll be.

For 170, my office hours were generally earlier in the week (i.e. I don't like holding office hours right on the day the homework is due, so I usually don't), and I can't recall a single occasion when I felt that I didn't have enough time to respond to all of the students (barring the OH right before the exam).

170 is also not a coding-based class, and so I didn't have to spend time trying to read/debug students' code. I think OH for that class is generally unlikely to be too rushed.

I've had students who only appear once or twice, and I've had regulars who just met with their study groups at my office hours. I think that the difference is more based on your personal preference.

Piazza can handle some (many) questions, but if the question is more involved (as some conceptual questions tend to be), I'll fairly strongly advocate asking in office hours. As an instructor, being able to gauge the student's understanding in real time and working on a whiteboard for visualizing are immensely useful in explaining concepts. (There have definitely been questions on Piazza that I've ignored because they're too tedious to explain there, but which would have been straightforward to answer in person. Also, some students aren't very good at asking questions and it's hard to figure out what the source of their confusion is via Piazza.)
Wow. What an mind-blowing answer. Steven Bi is THE CS God.

history.content:
Student posters, do you do old exams timed or untimed? Whole thing at once, or question by question with answer key?

From Prof. Sahai:

1) The most important thing to remember is that everone is different in how they learn, but the most direct path to doing well on exams is to actually understand the material well, understand how it connects to everything else that you have learned, and to have sufficient practice with the underlying technical skills to be able to execute on demand.

2) For many students, getting adequate sleep and rest is extremely important.  Relatedly, the general ability to concentrate and not be distracted for three hours straight is really important. So, don't shoot yourself in the foot by going into sleep debt, not eating properly, or allowing yourself to cultivate habits of distraction. Being able to do one thing at a tiMaking your own me for a long time isn't something that will just work on exams when you've spent all the time earlier in 3 minute work bursts interrupted by texts, youtube videos, etc... Marathoners don't train by just doing sprints.

3) Don't try to learn everything at the last minute. Really try to understand everything as the homeworks flow week by week. Don't just assume that you'll understand things better later. Ask the TAs and Profs for help earlier rather than later. 

4) In furtherance of your underlying understanding, the following approaches are woefully underused:

  • Making your own problems about the material, solving them, and sharing them with others.
  • It is often said that the best way to really learn something is to teach it. So, in general, doing versions of what the TAs and Profs do is a good idea. Make your own exam. Think about the concepts in the course, how they connect to other material in prereq courses and follow-on courses (ask your TAs or Prof if you do not understand this), and then try to make questions that hit those connections. After doing the practice exams as practice, deconstruct the problems and ask how you could make a similar question yourself? 
  • Pretend you are inside the material and understand how it fits together from the perspective of the computer or the math itself. Engage your artistic and imaginative side: try to escape the bounds of your individual human experience by stretching your ability to identify with the subject.  Don't be afraid to be silly. And don't be cynical --- every time you are cynical, you are just putting emotional distance between yourself and the material. That is not going to help you. The material has to become like a close friend --- you can get mad at it and frustrated at times, but you have to let yourself care and be vulnerable if you are going to really get close.
  • Play "stump your friend" with someone you care about and trust --- test each other about the material in a way that helps them understand better but don't destroy their confidence. If you end up stumping yourself, this is fine. Figure it out together.  
  • Don't be restricted to what you can see on the computer screen. Print stuff out and write stuff out by hand. Lay out the material in your own way so that it spatially spans many pages and you can see it all together spread out around you. The computer screen is too small to fully engage your visual memory.
Student posters, do you do old exams timed or untimed? Whole thing at once, or question by question with answer key?

children.subject: Please answer Nicole's instructor answer above! I really want to know the answer.

As a freshman who got an A in 61A and an A+ in 70, I'll chime in here - I do them untimed because I find that removing the pressure from the clock really helps. Keep in mind that there's often a common thread to test questions because there's only so many things that they can test, so once you find that common thread, tests become that much easier. As for the answer key, I like having immediate feedback, especially since one question doesn't really help or hinder the next, but I can see how individual preferences might vary.

Best of luck!

I'm rarely worried about not finishing an exam, so I never timed myself. If I was concerned about this, I would probably time only the last exam or two, at the very end of my preparation, to get a sense of pacing.

Whether or not I do it by-question is depending if I'm still in the learning-phase of studying (esp. in courses when I haven't really been following the course/doing the homework properly, and I'm using exams to figure out what I was supposed to have learned) or if I'm actually testing myself.

If it's the former, I'll usually read individual questions, think for a bit, and then go straight to reading the solution, since I presumably can't solve the problems.

If it's the latter, I'll write out semi-full solutions to all of the problems before checking my answers.
What a beautiful answer from Prof Sahai.
+1 the god himself has descended and given us spiritual revelations

"Don't be restricted to what you can see on the computer screen. Print stuff out and write stuff out by hand. Lay out the material in your own way so that it spatially spans many pages and you can see it all together spread out around you. The computer screen is too small to fully engage your visual memory"

This is poetic. This is why Berkeley EECS is #1 in the world, we have the best professors like Prof Sahai, who turned down Stanford and MIT for us. I still don't get why.

Prof Sahai, can you please answer @2957? ("Why did Prof Sahai choose Berkeley?") I've always wondered what attracted you to Berkeley. I love Berkeley, but it's really hard and would've chosen Stanford or MIT above it, especially to be a professor. What do you see in this place?
+1 I've always wondered this
+1 Need your life advice Professor
+1 Looking for an inspirational story or message
+1 Please answer this Sir!
+1 I'd love to hear your response Sir
+1 I had you in CS 70 in Spring 2014 but forgot to ask. Thank you sir!

You guys should watch Prof Sahai's first cs 70 lecture from Fall 2014. Its pretty inspiring because he talks about his background and also explains the motivation behind 70. If I remember correctly, he does go over why he chose Berkeley.

history.subject: Why is Math 110 useful in Machine Learning?
history.content: I don't see anything in Math 110 that's not taught in Math 54. Further, I don't see how anything beyond the basics of solving systems of equations is useful in ML. What's the point of eigenvalues, null space, subspaces, vector spaces, etc.?

history.subject: Why is Math 110 useful in Machine Learning?
history.content: I don't see anything in Math 110 that's not taught in Math 54. Further, I don't see how anything beyond the basics of solving systems of equations is useful in ML. What's the point of eigenvalues, null space, subspaces, vector spaces, etc.?

"Mathematical maturity" is helpful for CS 189 even if you learned nothing new about linear algebra itself in Math 110.  (Fortunately you do.)  A shortlist of useful things:

  • Eigenvalues/eigenvectors are used in spectral clustering.  They also allow for a geometric interpretation of Gaussian classifiers.  Additionally, eigenvalues have close ties to the concept of positive definiteness, which we use frequently.
  • Understanding nullspace/range is helpful for analyzing when a matrix is invertible.  Range is used as part of a geometric interpretation of ordinary least-squares regression.
  • 110 goes into much more detail about inner products, which are absolutely necessary for understanding kernel methods.

There's probably more that I've forgotten.  Others feel free to add stuff!

children.subject:
Hi Garrett, 

How would you define mathematical maturity? What is it about Math 110 that gives you maturity that Math 54 doesn't?

(not Garrett but) Basically the more you do math  / proofs / challenging problems the more mathematically mature you get. Think of it as math intuition. It's something that's not really taught, but it's something you gain by studying more math.
So 110 is 1) more challenging than 54, 2) way more rigorous than 54, 3) (well I took h110) but much more geometrically focused and geometry is pretty good for math maturity.

I took 189 last semester. Linear algebra showed up *all the time*. Like, every homework. Both the midterm and the final had linear algebra-flavored proofs.

Anyway, I found myself wishing I'd taken either 110 or 16B beforehand, just so I had more intuition about matrices. You can learn all the mechanical stuff (like row-reduction) fairly easily, but intuition is hard-earned.
Why is linear algebra so important though? This is a Machine Learning course. Not a Linear Algebra course.
Yeah, but ML (like many/most CS subfields) is just applied math.
AI/ML is especially mathy. Also graduate students also take it and graduate level cs is lots and lots of math.
What's the point of studying Computer Science then? Why don't we all just study math?
lol tons of CS PhDs working in the AMPLab are math undergrads.
yeah, exactly - that's my point.
Well, I like the mathy aspects of ML, but I like coding and software engineering too.

@Anon from 3 replies ago. Idk, that's a question for you. You signed up for this major, so you must of had your reasons, right? I'm not sure how it didn't dawn on you from 70, 170, and 188 that cs is a mathy discipline. At this point you just sound bitter.

Different offerings of the course have different emphases on math. Fall 2016 was more mathy because the professors (specifically Prof. Recht) believed that CS 189 = EE 126 + EE 127 + some notes on backprop, which is ultimately just a bunch of math.

If you take it next semester with Shewchuk, I believe you'll have a bit of a different experience. There is still def. alot of math, but I think the ML concepts are emphasized more.

Who's better, Hug or Shewshuck for ML?

Also, were you get rekt by Prof. Rect?

Didn't even know Hug was teaching it... from what I've heard, he was a pretty good 188 prof this past semester (I took it with Abbeel tho so I can't say for myself), but ultimately, 188 is actually quite different from 189 (way more concept based and waay less math). I think you should take it with Shewchuk though... just reading his notes on it give me a good impression of the way he taught the class.

Yeah I had Prof. Recht last semester. The class was really interesting, but to be quite blunt, it was the most disorganized CS class (or maybe just class in general) I've ever taken. Most people had to rely on student's notes or Shewchuk's notes because nothing was easy to find, lectures were in general kinda hard to understand and a little too simplistic at times. Idk if the TAs or the profs made the exams, but the midterm was brutal, and the final was pretty tough too (although imo way easier).

I took 189 last semester. Linear algebra showed up *all the time*. Like, every homework. Both the midterm and the final had linear algebra-flavored proofs.

Anyway, I found myself wishing I'd taken either 110 or 16B beforehand, just so I had more intuition about matrices. You can learn all the mechanical stuff (like row-reduction) fairly easily, but intuition is hard-earned.
Does it help to take Math 110 at the same time as CS189?
No, take it before.
Why Anon?
Math 110, especially the later parts, are used extensively in CS 189.
Is that your explanation as to why you shouldn't take it at the same time as CS189?
Yes, the later parts of 110 are really useful in the early parts of 189.
Maybe this is a better question: does it help for math 110 to take 189 at the same time?

Probably, although not by much. The repetition of the material would obviously help and an argument could definitely be made that, being able to see applications of the sometimes overtly conceptual subject matter in 110 (as you would in 189) would also help, but all in all, I doubt it'd do too much good for 110 to take 189 at the same time.

I think the reverse is definitely true though - I took 110 before 189 and felt that it helped me immensely. Can't imagine taking (and perhaps more importantly, doing particularly well in) 189 without the prior exposure to 110 or 110-esque material (don't know too much about 16B myself).

history.content:
Linear algebra is critical conceptually to understand what is actually going on in Machine Learning. This is one of the major reasons that 16A and 16B were built the way they are. The student answer is pretty good, to which I can just add that the discussion of the spectral theorem (eigenvalues/eigenvectors for symmetric matrices) and the SVD in 16B is also relevant. For EECS people, linear-algebra is not just a bag of tools. It is an important component of how we think. 

The idea is that 16B + hard work should get people to where they need to be. Math 54 by itself is not enough for most.

history.subject: Why don't Professors discuss their background & research?
history.content:
I'm a sophomore here, I've taken CS 61A, CS 61B, EE 16A and CS 70. None of my professors mention their background even though most of them are in the top 5 of their fields in the world.

The biggest benefit of going to such a great school is the top professors, but if the professors just focus on teaching and don't mention all the other things they know, what's the point of having such great professors?

Why not just hire some undergrads like Alvin Wan, Sinho Chewi, Yujie, Michael Zhang, Soroush, Kunal Mishra and Steven Bi as professors?

history.content:
I'm a freshman here. I've taken CS 61A, CS 61B and CS 70. None of my professors mention their background even though most of them are in the top 5 of their fields in the world.

history.subject: Why don't Professors discuss their background & research?
history.content:
I'm a freshman here. I've taken CS 61A, CS 61B and CS 70. None of my professors mention their background even though most of them are in the top 5 of their fields in the world.

The biggest benefit of going to such a great school is the top professors, but if the professors just focus on teaching and don't mention all the other things they know, what's the point of having such great professors?

Why not just hire some undergrads like Alvin Wan, Sinho Chewi, Yujie, Michael Zhang, Soroush, and Steven Bi?

Come to office hours and ask. Not everything fits in a large lecture. :-)

Our research perspective infuses all the courses, but in ways that are sometimes too subtle for the as yet untrained eye to perceive. (Faculty who visit from elsewhere often give us comments though, because they can see what we are doing underneath the surface that you perceive.) For example, 16AB were literally put together with cutting-edge research in mind (and new ways were developed research-style for the course itself), and the goal of innoculating students with the right patterns of thought to be able to participate and absorb the things that are coming down the pike. Not just 16AB --- some of the problems in CS70 as well are abstracted from ideas that arose in research contexts. DS8 is the same way. However, the connections between the research and the problems are sometimes obscured because the first duty of homework and lecture is to be digestible by students and help them grow (even if this growth sometimes leaves you a bit sore). 

The connections to research become slightly more visible in upper-division courses like 126, 127, 121, 123, 189, etc... (To speak about a few that I directly know about.) They are quite visible in graduate courses and completely out in the open in special topics courses (like the 194/294 course I will teach next semester). 

But as in all fields, there is a difference in perspective between a master and one who is beginning their education. Senior musicians and dancers will often go on and on about the importance of the foundations, because their mastery gives them a different perspective on the basics than the beginner has. It is no different in Engineering. That is why a high degree of faith and trust in your instructors is so important in education.  

Anyway, the fastest way to get access to a bit of the feel of the integration between research and teaching in the lower division is to join the content team for a course. There, you will see things more in the open as well.

children.subject:
OP Here. Professor Sahai, thanks a lot for your response! I had no idea research was so well integrated into our courses.


I just wish that Professors would relate what we're learning to what they're studying / current topics in the field. Professor Seshia is the world leader in computational proofs, but not once did he mention computational proofs in CS 70 this semester. Then what's the point of having him?

Your point is a good one.  Prof. Sahai correctly explained out that our research and startup experiences have a big

impact on what and how we teach, but to your point we may not be doing a good job of pointing that out during

lecture.  Often a short comment or parenthetical clause is all that it takes, but I think that sometimes the faculty

forget to do that.

I always try to throw references like that into my lectures and course material.  If you take ee140 from me, you'll do

your CMOS designs for the fictional startup Golden Bear Circuits, and you'll have a clear startup-relevant chip design task straight

from something that I've had exposure to through my consulting.

If you take ee147 from me, you'll get a lot of comments like "and that simple idea is what launched the billion dollar

MEMS accelerometer industry" or "and those five boxes drawn just right got me a PhD in '92."

In addition to going to office hours to ask questions, I would encourage you to ask questions in lecture periodically

as well, either before or during class, about how what you are learning is related to research and commercial practice.

Is Prof. Seshia the world leader in computational proofs? I knew he was really smart but the world leader? As my professor for CS 70? Boy, Berkeley has a serious problem. Students need to be aware of this.

history.subject: Intuition behind Machine Learning.
history.content:
I am TAing for CS 189 next semester. Before that, I thought I should properly understand what ML actually IS. I help lead Machine Learning at Berkeley and currently research in Prof. Wagner's lab. I've also published several papers on deep learning. Over the summer, I interned on Google's self driving car team. But I never truly grasped what ML is. So I present this question, which has been eating at me for months.

If machines can learn, why can't they teach? Why can't they think? Reason? Worship? Why are we focusing on Machine LEARNING instead all of these other possibilities? A machine that can think is far more intelligent than one that can simply learn. So we should be focusing on that instead.

children.subject: OP: Are you Steven Bi? You are a CS God.

I have no idea what part of this post (either in the author's background or writing style) suggests that I made the post, or why I would acknowledge making a post that I had made anonymously if I had done so.

The OP is a CS God. Look at his achievements. He is in the top 0.1% of Berkeley students. I wouldn't  be surprised if he's a billionare at 25.

Steven Bi is also a CS God.

Therefore, Steven Bi might be OP.
Taken together, don't the koan and Steven Bi's response imply that the OP is Steven Bi?

I'm pretty sure that the OP is trolling with us....

If you are not (and indeed going to be a 189 TA next semester), can you reveal your identity?
I would prefer to stay anonymous.
People have edited the OP's post, use the history slider to see.

history.content:
Never confuse an argument about linguistics with an argument about the world. The following koan was taught to me by Chomsky in the context of Turing and Searle, and who was referring to wisdom passed down from Dijkstra. (I'm adapting it.)

A disciple approached Basho and inquired about the nature of artificial intelligence.

Basho: "Do birds fly?"

Disciple: "Yes."

Basho: "Do airplanes fly?"

Disciple: "Yes."

Basho: "Do fish swim?"

Disciple: "Yes."

Basho: "Do submarines swim?"

Disciple: "No."

Basho: "Why do airplanes fly but submarines don't swim?"

Upon hearing this, the disciple was enlightened. He proceeded to do something useful like learn linear algebra, optimization, and probability. 

Reflect upon this and you will pass the zeroth gate of modern AI.

children.subject: Can someone clarify Professor Sahai's answer? I don't fully understand what the story's message is.

If a computer program is so good that it for all purposes seem to think and respond intelligently, then we may as well call it thinking, even if it's just algorithms underneath. People don't say a sub "swims", but since it can achieve the same purpose, it basically swims. (Just as we say the airplane "flies".)

Sorry if that was long-winded, English is not my native language. Does it make more sense now?

history.subject: Practical Math/Stats Courses
history.content:
I really love "practical" math courses. In other words, math courses that teach you to solve real world problems. 

For example, CS 70 and EE 126 give you the tools (Markov Chains, Expectation, etc) to model a lot of real world phenomena. On the other hand, Math 54 is really theoretical: Vector spaces, basis, rank, null space. Math 54 is useful but only in EE 16A did I appreciate linear algebra.

So, my question is, what other practical math courses do you suggest? They don't need to be in Math DepartmentThey don't even need to be math courses: Game Theory isn't math but (1) its practical and (2) it's analysed like math. 

Here are some I'd like, please suggest more!

- STAT 150: Stochastic Processes
- STAT 153: Intro to Time Series
- STAT 155: Game Theory

- INDENG 166: Decision Analysis

- INDENG 267: Queueing Theory

- PUB POL 259: Cost Benefit Analysis

- PHIL 143: Modal Logic

children.subject: Math 54 is theoretical but also very practical since the concepts taught are used in a lot of different places in CS. I'm not sure why you think its not useful. Do you mean an applications based class? Try CS189 maybe.

"Math 54 is useful but only in EE 16A did I appreciate linear algebra."

I think Math 54 is useful, but its not applications focused. EE 16A teaches you a lot of the same material, but teaches you applications of each linear algebra topic as well.

Try EE128 Feedback Control.  You get to find out how vector spaces, basis, rank, and null space all relate

to getting the best possible performance out of physical systems.  Labs include real-world examples

like stabilizing an inverted pendulum and magnetic levitation, but applications include anything

with behavior governed by differential equations (which is basically everything from machines to networks

to economics), and all of it is very closely tied to some beautiful mathematics.

Understand the math, control the world!

EPS 104: Mathematical Methods for Geophysics. It does cover a lot of earth science (fluid mechanics, continuum mechanics, etc.), but it is mostly math. It essentially covers most of Math 121A/B: review of vectors, matrices, and tensors, Fourier series, how to solve various types of differential equations, Green's function, Bessel's function, Fourier transforms, complex analysis/integration, and convolution. The professor is awesome and really enthusiastic about the material.
OP Here. Looks interesting! Added it to my classes to take list!
Anyone have thoughts on INDENG 166 (Decision Analysis)? I might take it in the future.
OP Here. Same question. Seems interesting but I have no idea what to expect.

history.subject: Is 61A/70 Tutor hiring done already?
history.content: I know these classes typically release offers very late, but are they done hiring for tutors/readers? If so, do you get an email if you are not selected?

70 has not started hiring tutors/readers.  It is generally done near the beginning of

the semester, after upper division readers are hired.

children.subject: Thanks! How many readers do they typically hire, and who makes the decisions: the TA's or professors?
Depends on the semester. The hiring is done by a faculty member so the professor.

history.subject: GPA to get into grad school?
history.content: What GPA do I need to get into a decent grad program (top 10)?

history.subject: GPA to get into grad school?
history.content: What GPA do I need to get into a decent grad program (top 15)?

3.7 or above (at least).

But it also depends on other things.
3.7 or above (at least).

children.subject: What other things.
Letters of rec, GRE score, research, extracurriculars

Everything I've heard from professors is that letters of rec >>>>>>> everything else, including grades. Stellar letters can make up for any deficiency in other areas. But a 4.0/amazing extracurriculars are not going to make up for mediocre letters.
Agreed^ professors are looking for people they want to do research with and would perform that research well, not someone only made up of numbers.
Aren't "decent" and "top 10" very different terms?
Not if OP has very high standards...

The challenge to answering that question is that admissions decisions are made by very small groups of people,

sometimes just one person, depending on the institution, department, research area, year, etc.

Unfortunately there is a significant amount of randomness in the process.

As others have said, letters, or usually just one letter, make the biggest difference.  Most of us are looking

for a letter that says "this student participated in my research group at the level of my first year grad students.

I would be happy to have her/him join my research group".  That letter and a 3.9 from Berkeley is going to get

you in to many/most good schools.  That letter and a 3.2 *might* get you in to a top 10 school.  20 years ago

when I did admissions at UCLA we'd admit a 3.2 from Berkeley in solid state, but no one with less than a 4.0 

from anywhere got admitted in communications theory (times have changed, that's just for example, not 

representative of what happens at UCLA today).

A letter that says "this person took a class from me and got an A+.  S/he seems smart." is next to worthless.

We see the transcript, we know what grades you got.  I *hate* that students feel like they need to get three

letters, even if they only really know one or two faculty members.  In my opinion, those meaningless letters

actually hurt your application, as they water down the one or two good letters that you already have.
Thanks professor!

I know this is an old thread, but I'd just like to add that several top engineering graduate programs require having three letters of recommendation.  Building strong bonds with faculty members in the span of an undergraduate career can be quite challenging!

history.subject: EE105 v CS170
history.content: Which is bigger workload

That is going to depend a lot on how your brain is wired.

Stephen Hawking said that he went into theoretic physics because everything else

was too hard.

Check out the results of the hkn course surveys.  In the most recent semester students rated ee105 as 3.3/5 

with regard to "Workload is heavier than for courses of comparable credit" whereas cs170 was 4.3/5.

So at least that semester ee105 was probably a lower workload.

history.subject: Undergraduate Research
history.content: I am a sophomore and was wondering if there are any research opportunities for a person with my level of experience. (Taken 61A, 61B, 70, Currently taking 188)

children.subject: Check beehive! There's usually a decent amount of opportunities there

history.content: there is a helpful handout on various ways to find research located outside of 205 Cory.

children.subject: Asking around (maybe former TAs are of assistance here) might also be useful.

Short answer: yes.

Longer answer:

 It can take a while to find one.  Talking to your TAs is good.  Going to office hours is good.

Asking professors about their research and if they have open research group meetings is

a good idea.

In my group, undergrads are always welcome to come and listen.  Most of your first meeting will

be incomprehensible.  As you come back you'll start to figure out some of the themes - these 

people are working on the radio+microprocessor chip, these people are working on the motors

and mechanisms for silicon ants, this guy is trying to get his flying postage stamp to take off.

All of them occasionally need someone to help them take data or write software.  Once you've

shown that you are reliable and show up when you say you will, you'll start getting more

opportunities, and more interesting things to work on.
How does an undergraduate student get an invitation to these meetings? Is this something that would come about as a result of asking professors about research opportunities?
exactly.

history.subject: Change EE147 into a 4-unit class
history.content: This might not be the right place to ask but last semester I took EE147 as one of my upper div requirements for EECS major. However, since it was only 3-unit, I had to take one additional class to fulfill the 20 unit upper div requirement (usually 5 upper divs). So I looked back on the structure of EE147 and found that it had 3 hours of lectures and 1 hour of discussion weekly, which was exactly the same as most of 4-unit CS upper divs. The amount of workload was, at least to me, same as the other 4-unit classes. Why is it 3-unit instead of 4-unit? Is there anyone that's in charge of class administration? Who should I write to?

history.subject: Change EE147 into a 4-unit class
history.content: This might not be the right place to ask but last semester I took EE147 as one of my upper div requirements for EECS major. However, since it was only 3-unit, I had to take one additional class to fulfill the 20 unit upper div requirement. So I looked back on the structure of EE147 and found that it had 3 hours of lectures and 1 hour of discussion weekly, which was exactly the same as most of 4-unit CS upper divs. The amount of workload was, at least to me, same as the other 4-unit classes. Why is it 3-unit instead of 4-unit? Is there anyone that's in charge of class administration? Who should I write to?

Courses are carefully evaluated by COCI (Committee on Courses of Instruction) and the Academic Senate. According to the Course Management System, this course meets for 3 hours of lecture and 1 hour of discussion/week, but it has no lab. This may be why it is 3 units instead of 4.

children.subject:
I need to change that.  Sarah is right that COCI has final authority, but the instructor (me) needs to submit the right

paperwork or they won't consider the change.

Last semester I taught a 2 unit class on micro robot design as a companion class to 147/247A so that people who

needed the extra unit could have a way to get it.

history.subject: Inadequacy after learning concepts
history.content:
After learning most concepts, I feel inadequate because I know in the real world, they're not using this concept: They're using something much more sophisticated.

For example, Error Correcting Codes (CS 70): The ECCs we learn were discovered in the 1970s. Today's ECCs use much more complex techniques involving abstract algebra.

Why learn these basic concepts if in the real world, I'll need to use something much more complex? And knowing the basic case won't help me (I'll need to learn abstract algebra which this approach doesn't require)

Professors don't have the time to go over the state of the art method for every topic. Imagine if computer architecture, for example, was taught this way. There is no way to fit the complexity of a certain topic within 3 hours of lecture a week. Learning these topics are meant to give you a well-rounded, basic understanding of many different areas of a field.

Also, not everything has to be geared for application in the real world. Sometimes you can learn just for the sake of learning (or enjoyment).

I can totally understand where you are coming from, but I have come to the conclusion that we are not taught about specific details because a large portion of those details will be outdated very soon anyway. In essence, our professors teach us HOW to learn and hope to spark interest in the more advanced/modern trends out there in the real world.

Professors don't have the time to go over the state of the art method for every topic. Imagine if computer architecture, for example, was taught this way. There is no way to fit the complexity of a certain topic within 3 hours of lecture a week. Learning these topics are meant to give you a well-rounded, basic understanding of many different areas of a field.

Also, not everything has to be geared for application in the real world. Sometimes you can learn just for the sake of learning (or enjoyment).

Professors don't have the time to go over the state of the art method for every topic. Imagine if computer architecture, for example, was taught this way. There is no way to fit the complexity of a certain topic within 3 hours of lecture a week. Learning these topics are meant to give you a well-rounded, basic understanding of many different areas of a field.

The basics are what are the most important over a long career. You need to understand the core idea of something before you can understand other manifestations of the idea as well as extensions. EECS courses aren't cookbooks with recipes for you to follow. And in the lower-division at least, many things are taught to you in a way that does double or triple duty --- you are not just being taught about X, but also how to think more generally, as well as learning ideas that are more broadly applicable. 

For error correcting codes themselves, EE229B talks about them in more detail and brings you closer to the state of the art. This is not to say that the codes taught in 70 aren't useful today --- many modern implementations take the ideas of Reed Solomon codes taught in 70 and make things more efficient by exploiting ideas of extension fields (taught in EE229B and Math 114 I believe). There are also other qualitatively distinct code families, namely the polar codes, LDPC codes, and turbo codes, that are increasingly popular today in cutting-edge applications. To understand LDPC and Turbo code constructions and implementations, you need to understand more about message-passing inference algorithms as well as things like linear programming and optimization. To understand polar codes, you need more information theory (EE229A) as well. These modern families build more directly on the material in *core* EECS courses like 126, 127, etc. rather than on the algebra and algebraic geometry underlying other codes in the Reed Solomon style.

Remember, a Bachelor's degree gives you the education you need to be an apprentice that learns on the job, and can keep on learning for the next 4+ decades. It cannot make you a master at anything without sacrificing your long-term future for an ephemeral gain in the present. Lower-division is designed to help you build a solid foundation to prepare you for *learning* more advanced material.

history.subject: Summer EE16A. Lecture mandatory?
history.content: Recently announced that STAT134 would change its lecture time and now conflicts with EE16A lecture in the summer. Has EE16A lecture ever been mandatory?

16A lecture isn't mandatory this semester.  This semester, 16A doesn't accommodate final exam conflicts caused by other classes.

Policies may change for the summer.

Not attending lecture is not a good idea. 

Summer policy has not been set. But not attending lecture in summer is an even worse idea than not attending lecture during the semester. In summer, everything is going twice as fast. You're not expected to be able to take any more than a single course at a time.

history.subject: CS 188 with CS 70
history.content: Has anyone taken these courses together? Thoughts? Thank you!

children.subject: I haven't taken them together, but a portion of CS188 builds on Bayes' theorem which is taught in the second half of CS70. For students without prior probability experience it may be new and unintuitive, but reading ahead in CS70 can fix that.
Bayes' rule you mean?
Both are names for the same thing.

I've TA'd for both. and I've seen students who take both concurrently. (I don't know how they did / can't comment on their experience.)

As the anon above notes, the way in which 188 depends on 70 is primarily the probability part, which is the basis for a substantial part of 188, especially in the MT2 material. (At a rough estimate, 80% of the problems on MT2 are probability-related.) 70 teaches this material in the second half of the course, which is after 188 has started covering the topics.

Of course, it's always possible to self-study the material, and 188 spends some effort in helping students review the prerequisite material (because even among students who did take 70, some have forgotten lots of the key concepts). 

And I'm always emphasized to my students that the 188's MT2 really requires students to be super-comfortable (i.e. fast) with working with probability (e.g. doing Bayesian inference), and just a 70-level familiarity with probability is likely not sufficient, so all students would be spending effort in this area anyway.

The concept of expectation (taught after probability in 70) is also useful in 188 in order to understand how we calculate utilities (MT1), analyze MDPs (MT1), and calculate VPIs (MT2), although 188 kind of skims over the details of how expectation is used.

In summary, I wouldn't ignore 70 as a prereq for 188, but this is probably doable with sufficient extra effort. Reading ahead in the 70 notes certainly helps to learn/understand the concepts, but spending time working on 188 problems would likely help more in building familiarity.

For a subset of some opinions of other students answering the same question.

https://www.facebook.com/groups/631097886985088/permalink/747604238667785/

https://www.facebook.com/groups/631097886985088/permalink/701382446623298/ (Note that Dibyo's comment no longer applies)

https://www.facebook.com/groups/berkeleycs/permalink/580910152003862/

I would personally say no no. First half of CS188 is very similar to some parts of CS 70. For example, understanding/analyzing how Stable Marriage Algorithm runs is a pretty import indirect skill for CS188 algorithms (A*, minmax, CSP, Markov etc...). Also, the second half of CS188 depends on probs from CS70. I don't think it's a good combo. The question "whether it's doable" is misleading because everything is doable with enough effort. But imho this particular one is too much and would be detrimental to learning experience.

I did both last semester. It went fine! They had no overlap that I can think of, except for basic probability rules (Bayes' Law, etc.), and maybe a little bit of stuff about Markov chains. There's no issue taking them together.
+1 I also did this and it was totally fine.
I took them together last semester and I had no problem.
thank you all, super helpful!!

Nicole, I think that the official advice is a very loud "DO NOT DO THIS" for taking 188 without having taken 70, especially when we are talking about our majors. 

I think that any student who violates prerequisites without instructor permission ethically needs to promise to not attend office hours with any difficulties regarding the material, not to be in a study group with any student who has taken the prerequisites, and not to ask questions on either piazza or in discussion section. It is incredibly rude to distort the learning experience for other students because the student couldn't be bothered to actually be prepared. It makes life harder for the TAs as well. Yes, there are a small fraction of students who can do this without causing a disruption. Those students also shouldn't need to ask any questions or work with anyone. For a larger fraction, it only *seems* to work but the students have gaps and holes in their understanding. Another group muddles through, knowing that they are confused, but just counting on others to help them get through it. There is a reason why lower division material is lower division --- to make sure that students master it and have a solid foundation to build upon. For every student for whom it makes sense to skip a prerequisite, there are a lot more who are caught up in an immature subculture of fake bravado and showing off. This should not be encouraged at all.

Hi Prof. Sahai, I appreciate your reasoning, but I do respectfully disagree. It really depends on the student. For motivated students who have maybe done competition math and algorithmic coding challenges in high school, this should hopefully not constrain them. And there are lots of these kind of students here, I would not say it's a very small fraction. I have taken cs 70 and 188, and the 188 probability (conditioning, total prob, bayes) is just stuff I learned in high school. More so, some of these prereqs are outdated and don't make much logical sense. For example for 189 it was a prereq in the past to take 188, but now that's gone and for a good reason.

Is 16A not a pre-requisite for 16B? I seem to remember a post where you, Professor Sahai, tell students to do Math 54+16B without taking 16A, despite content from 16A being needed in 16B. Why is this the exception, despite 188 using similar levels of content from 70 as 16B does from 16A?

I think that might be because Math 54 has a lot of redundancy with 16A but doesn't teach for example SVD which is in 16B? So, for people who have taken 54 and 110 like me, 16A is kind of a waste of time...

history.subject: Change to lower division EE & linear algebra requirements for LSCS
history.content:
UPDATE 7/24/17: these requirements have been approved since the original date of this post, for new requirements see this page. Current LSCS referred to here are students who have been admitted prior to Fall 2017.

Effective once L&S executive committee approves (and we don't expect that to take more than 1 or 2 months max), current LSCS students will have some additional options to fulfill the lower division EE and linear algebra requirements.

Students can choose from the following options:

  1. EE 16A and EE 16B (recommended)
  2. Math 54 and EE 16A
  3. Math 54 and EE 16B

history.subject: Change to lower division EE & linear algebra requirements for LSCS
history.content:
UPDATE: this has been approved, for new requirements see this page. Current LSCS referred to here are students who have been admitted prior to Fall 2017.

Effective once L&S executive committee approves (and we don't expect that to take more than 1 or 2 months max), current LSCS students will have some additional options to fulfill the lower division EE and linear algebra requirements.

Students can choose from the following options:

  1. EE 16A and EE 16B (recommended)
  2. Math 54 and EE 16A
  3. Math 54 and EE 16B
